description:
Fusarium fujikuroi IMI 58289 is a species of filamentous fungus that belongs to the genus Fusarium. This strain, designated as IMI 58289, was originally isolated and deposited in the International Mycological Institute (IMI) culture collection.

Fusarium fujikuroi is known to be the causal agent of the rice disease known as "bakanae" or "foolish seedling" in various parts of the world. The fungus can produce a range of secondary metabolites, including the plant growth hormone gibberellin, which can lead to the characteristic overgrowth and abnormal elongation of rice seedlings.

As a member of the Fusarium genus, F. fujikuroi IMI 58289 is typically characterized by its fast-growing, cottony mycelium, and the production of various types of asexual spores, including macroconidia and microconidia. The species can be further distinguished from other Fusarium species based on its morphological features, such as the shape and size of the macroconidia, as well as its unique genetic fingerprint.

Due to its agricultural importance and potential for producing valuable fungal metabolites, the F. fujikuroi IMI 58289 strain has been the subject of various research studies, focusing on topics such as its pathogenicity, metabolism, and potential biotechnological applications.
